thread.title: Total solar eclipse 2017: Stunning images show moment the Moon completely obscured the Sun - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Total solar eclipse 2017: Stunning images show moment the Moon completely obscured the Sun - Mirror Online

author: Jeff Parsons
title: Total solar eclipse 2017: Stunning images show moment the Moon completely obscured the Sun - Mirror Online
text:
The eclipse began at 12.10 GMT, reach its maximum point at 14.58 GMT and set at 17.35 GMT. 
It was first visible in Chile before passing over Argentina's Patagonia region. 
Sky watchers could see it across the South Atlantic Ocean and eventually in Angola. (Photo: AFP) (Photo: AFP) 
It was last visible above the border of Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo at sunset. 
The first of two solar eclipses happening in 2017, the next is due to be seen over the USA on August 21. 
New theory sheds light on how the Moon was formed - and why we have a 24-hour day Why does a solar eclipse happen? 
Solar eclipses are due to the moon's orbital tilt which causes it to pass between the Earth and the Sun. 
However, they occur very rarely because the moon orbits at an angle of 5 degrees off the Earth's own orbital plane around the sun, and spins on an axis that is actually tilted towards our own planet. (Photo: AFP) When is the next Solar Eclipse in the UK? 
We won't see another eclipse over these shores until June 10, 2021. 
Then a partial eclipse will take place across Britain ranging from 50% in northern Scotland to 30% in south-east England. Like us on Facebook
